6.1.5 Random Vectors

When dealing with multiple random variables, it is sometimes useful to use vector and matrix notations. This makes the formulas more compact and lets us use facts from linear algebra. In this section, we briefly explore this avenue. The reader should be familiar with matrix algebra before reading this section. When we have nn random variables X1X1, X2X2, ..., XnXn we can put them in a (column) vector XX:
X=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢X1X2...Xn⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥.X=[X1X2...Xn].
We call XX a random vector. Here XX is an nn-dimensional vector because it consists of nn random variables. In this book, we usually use bold capital letters such as X,YX,Y and ZZ to represent a random vector. To show a possible value of a random vector we usually use bold lowercase letters such as x, y and z. Thus, we can write the CDF of the random vector XX as
FX(x)=FX1,X2,...,Xn(x1,x2,...,xn)=P(X1≤x1,X2≤x2,...,Xn≤xn).FX(x)=FX1,X2,...,Xn(x1,x2,...,xn)=P(X1≤x1,X2≤x2,...,Xn≤xn).
If the XiXi's are jointly continuous, the PDF of X can be written as
fX(x)=fX1,X2,...,Xn(x1,x2,...,xn).fX(x)=fX1,X2,...,Xn(x1,x2,...,xn).

Expectation:

The expected value vector or the mean vector of the random vector X is defined as
EX=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢EX1EX2...EXn⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥.EX=[EX1EX2...EXn].
Similarly, a random matrix is a matrix whose elements are random variables. In particular, we can have an mm by nn random matrix M as
M=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢X11X21...Xm1X12X22...Xm2............X1nX2n...Xmn⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥.M=[X11X12...X1nX21X22...X2n............Xm1Xm2...Xmn].
We sometimes write this as M=[Xij]=[Xij], which means that XijXij is the element in the iith row and jjth column of M. The mean matrix of M is given by
EM=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢EX11EX21...EXm1EX12EX22...EXm2............EX1nEX2n...EXmn⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥.EM=[EX11EX12...EX1nEX21EX22...EX2n............EXm1EXm2...EXmn].
Linearity of expectation is also valid for random vectors and matrices. In particular, let X be an nn-dimensional random vector and the random vector Y be defined as
Y=AX+b,Y=AX+b,
where A is a fixed (non-random) mm by nn matrix and b is a fixed mm-dimensional vector. Then we have
EY=AEX+b.EY=AEX+b.
Also, if X1,X2,⋯,XkX1,X2,⋯,Xk are nn-dimensional random vectors, then we have
E[X1+X2+⋯+Xk]=EX1+EX2+⋯+EXk.E[X1+X2+⋯+Xk]=EX1+EX2+⋯+EXk.

Correlation and Covariance Matrix

For a random vector XX, we define the correlation matrix, RXRX, as
RX=E[XXT]=E⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢X21X2X1...XnX1X1X2X22...XnX2............X1XnX2Xn...X2n⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢EX21EX2X1...E[XnX1]E[X1X2]E[X22]...E[XnX2]............E[X1Xn]E[X2Xn]...E[X2n]⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥,RX=E[XXT]=E[X12X1X2...X1XnX2X1X22...X2Xn............XnX1XnX2...Xn2]=[EX12E[X1X2]...E[X1Xn]EX2X1E[X22]...E[X2Xn]............E[XnX1]E[XnX2]...E[Xn2]],
where TT shows matrix transposition.

The covariance matrix, CXCX, is defined as
CX=E[(X−EX)(X−EX)T]=E⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢(X1−EX1)2(X2−EX2)(X1−EX1)...(Xn−EXn)(X1−EX1)(X1−EX1)(X2−EX2)(X2−EX2)2...(Xn−EXn)(X2−EX2)............(X1−EX1)(Xn−EXn)(X2−EX2)(Xn−EXn)...(Xn−EXn)2⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢Var(X1)Cov(X2,X1)...Cov(Xn,X1)Cov(X1,X2)Var(X2)...Cov(XnX2)............Cov(X1,Xn)Cov(X2,Xn)...Var(Xn)⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥.CX=E[(X−EX)(X−EX)T]=E[(X1−EX1)2(X1−EX1)(X2−EX2)...(X1−EX1)(Xn−EXn)(X2−EX2)(X1−EX1)(X2−EX2)2...(X2−EX2)(Xn−EXn)............(Xn−EXn)(X1−EX1)(Xn−EXn)(X2−EX2)...(Xn−EXn)2]=[Var(X1)Cov(X1,X2)...Cov(X1,Xn)Cov(X2,X1)Var(X2)...Cov(X2,Xn)............Cov(Xn,X1)Cov(XnX2)...Var(Xn)].
The covariance matrix is a generalization of the variance of a random variable. Remember that for a random variable, we have Var(X)=EX2−(EX)2Var(X)=EX2−(EX)2. The following example extends this formula to random vectors.
Example
For a random vector X, show
CX=RX−EXEXT.CX=RX−EXEXT.
  • Solution
    • We have
      CX=E[(X−EX)(X−EX)T]=E[(X−EX)(XT−EXT)]=E[XXT]−EXEXT−EXEXT+EXEXT(by linearity of expectation)=RX−EXEXT.CX=E[(X−EX)(X−EX)T]=E[(X−EX)(XT−EXT)]=E[XXT]−EXEXT−EXEXT+EXEXT(by linearity of expectation)=RX−EXEXT.

Correlation matrix of X: RX=E[XXT]Covariance matrix of X: CX=E[(X−EX)(X−EX)T]=RX−EXEXTCorrelation matrix of X: RX=E[XXT]Covariance matrix of X: CX=E[(X−EX)(X−EX)T]=RX−EXEXT
Example
Let X be an nn-dimensional random vector and the random vector Y be defined as
Y=AX+b,Y=AX+b,
where A is a fixed mm by nn matrix and b is a fixed mm-dimensional vector. Show that
CY=ACXAT.CY=ACXAT.
  • Solution
    • Note that by linearity of expectation, we have
      EY=AEX+b.EY=AEX+b.
      By definition, we have
      CY=E[(Y−EY)(Y−EY)T]=E[(AX+b−AEX−b)(AX+b−AEX−b)T]=E[A(X−EX)(X−EX)TAT]=AE[(X−EX)(X−EX)T]AT=ACXAT.(by linearity of expectation)CY=E[(Y−EY)(Y−EY)T]=E[(AX+b−AEX−b)(AX+b−AEX−b)T]=E[A(X−EX)(X−EX)TAT]=AE[(X−EX)(X−EX)T]AT(by linearity of expectation)=ACXAT.

Example
Let XX and YY be two jointly continuous random variables with joint PDF
fX,Y(x,y)=⎧⎩⎨⎪⎪32x2+y00<x,y<1otherwisefX,Y(x,y)={32x2+y0<x,y<10otherwise
and let the random vector U be defined as
U=[XY].U=[XY].
Find the correlation and covariance matrices of U.
  • Solution
    • We first obtain the marginal PDFs of XX and YY. Note that RX=RY=(0,1)RX=RY=(0,1). We have for x∈RXx∈RX
      fX(x)=∫1032x2+ydy=32x2+12,for 0<x<1.fX(x)=∫0132x2+ydy=32x2+12,for 0<x<1.
      Similarly, for y∈RYy∈RY, we have
      fY(y)=∫1032x2+ydx=y+12,for 0<y<1.fY(y)=∫0132x2+ydx=y+12,for 0<y<1.
      From these, we obtain EX=58EX=58, EX2=715EX2=715, EY=712EY=712, and EY2=512EY2=512. We also need EXYEXY. By LOTUS, we can write
      EXY=∫10∫10xy(32x2+y)dxdy=∫1038y+12y2dy=1748.EXY=∫01∫01xy(32x2+y)dxdy=∫0138y+12y2dy=1748.
      From this, we also obtain
      Cov(X,Y)=EXY−EXEY=1748−58.712=−196.Cov(X,Y)=EXY−EXEY=1748−58.712=−196.
      The correlation matrix RURU is given by
      RU=E[UUT]=[EX2EYXEXYEY2]=⎡⎣71517481748512⎤⎦.RU=E[UUT]=[EX2EXYEYXEY2]=[71517481748512].
      The covariance matrix CUCU is given by
      CU=[Var(X)Cov(Y,X)Cov(X,Y)Var(Y)]=⎡⎣73960−196−19611144⎤⎦.CU=[Var(X)Cov(X,Y)Cov(Y,X)Var(Y)]=[73960−196−19611144].

Properties of the Covariance Matrix:

The covariance matrix is the generalization of the variance to random vectors. It is an important matrix and is used extensively. Let's take a moment and discuss its properties. Here, we use concepts from linear algebra such as eigenvalues and positive definiteness. First note that, for any random vector X, the covariance matrix CXCX is a symmetric matrix. This is because if CX=[cij]CX=[cij], then
cij=Cov(Xi,Xj)=Cov(Xj,Xi)=cji.cij=Cov(Xi,Xj)=Cov(Xj,Xi)=cji.
Thus, the covariance matrix has all the nice properties of symmetric matrices. In particular, CXCX can be diagonalized and all the eigenvalues of CXCX are real. Here, we assume X is a real random vector, i.e., the XiXi's can only take real values. A special important property of the covariance matrix is that it is positive semi-definite (PSD). Remember from linear algebra that a symmetric matrix M is positive semi-definite (PSD) if, for all vectors b, we have
bTMb≥0.bTMb≥0.
Also, M is said to be positive definite (PD), if for all vectors b≠0≠0, we have
bTMb>0.bTMb>0.
By the above definitions, we note that every PD matrix is also PSD, but the converse is not generally true. Here, we show that covariance matrices are always PSD.
Theorem . Let XX be a random vector with nn elements. Then, its covariance matrix CXCX is positive semi-definite(PSD).
Proof. Let b be any fixed vector with nn elements. Define the random variable YY as
Y=bT(X−EX).Y=bT(X−EX).
We have
0≤EY2=E(YYT)=bTE[(X−EX)(X−EX)T]b=bTCXb.0≤EY2=E(YYT)=bTE[(X−EX)(X−EX)T]b=bTCXb.
Note that the eigenvalues of a PSD matrix are always larger than or equal to zero. If all the eigenvalues are strictly larger than zero, then the matrix is positive definite. From linear algebra, we know that a real symmetric matrix is positive definite if and only if all its eigenvalues are positive. Since CXCX is a real symmetric matrix, we can state the following theorem.
Theorem . Let XX be a random vector with nn elements. Then its covariance matrix CXCX is positive definite (PD), if and only if all its eigenvalues are larger than zero. Equivalently, CXCX is positive definite (PD), if and only if det(CX)>0det(CX)>0.
Note that the second part of the theorem is implied by the first part. This is because the determinant of a matrix is the product of its eigenvalues, and we already know that all eigenvalues of CXCX are larger than or equal to zero.
Example
Let XX and YY be two independent Uniform(0,1)Uniform(0,1) random variables. Let the random vectors U and V be defined as
U=[XX+Y],V=⎡⎣⎢XYX+Y⎤⎦⎥.U=[XX+Y],V=[XYX+Y].
Determine whether CUCU and CVCV are positive definite.
  • Solution
    • Let us first find CUCU. We have
      CU=[Var(X)Cov(X+Y,X)Cov(X,X+Y)Var(X+Y)].CU=[Var(X)Cov(X,X+Y)Cov(X+Y,X)Var(X+Y)].
      Since XX and YY are independent Uniform(0,1)Uniform(0,1) random variables, we have
      Var(X)=Var(Cov(X,X+Y)Var(X+Y)=Y)=112,=Cov(X,X)+Cov(X,Y)=112+0=112,Var(X)+Var(Y)=16.Var(X)=Var(Y)=112,Cov(X,X+Y)=Cov(X,X)+Cov(X,Y)=112+0=112,Var(X+Y)=Var(X)+Var(Y)=16.
      Thus,
      CU=⎡⎣11211211216⎤⎦.CU=[11211211216].
      So we conclude
      det(CU)=112.16−112.112=1144>0.det(CU)=112.16−112.112=1144>0.
      Therefore, CUCU is positive definite. For CVCV, we have
      CV=⎡⎣⎢Var(X)Cov(Y,X)Cov(X+Y,X)Cov(X,Y)Var(Y)Cov(X+Y,Y)Cov(X,X+Y)Cov(Y,X+Y)Var(X+Y)⎤⎦⎥=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢1120112011211211211216⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥.CV=[Var(X)Cov(X,Y)Cov(X,X+Y)Cov(Y,X)Var(Y)Cov(Y,X+Y)Cov(X+Y,X)Cov(X+Y,Y)Var(X+Y)]=[1120112011211211211216].
      So we conclude
      det(CV)=112(112⋅16−112⋅112)−0+112(0−112⋅112)=0.det(CV)=112(112⋅16−112⋅112)−0+112(0−112⋅112)=0.
      Thus, CVCV is not positive definite (we already know that it is positive semi-definite).

Finally, if we have two random vectors, XX and YY, we can define the cross correlation matrix of XX and YY as
RXY=E[XYT].RXY=E[XYT].
Also, the cross covariance matrix of X and Y is
CXY=E[(X−EX)(Y−EY)T].CXY=E[(X−EX)(Y−EY)T].

Functions of Random Vectors: The Method of Transformations

A function of a random vector is a random vector. Thus, the methods that we discussed regarding functions of two random variables can be used to find distributions of functions of random vectors. For example, we can state a more general form of Theorem 5.1 (method of transformations). Let us first explain the method and then see some examples on how to use it. Let XX be an nn-dimensional random vector with joint PDF fX(x)fX(x). Let G:Rn↦RnG:Rn↦Rn be a continuous and invertible function with continuous partial derivatives and let H=G−1H=G−1. Suppose that the random vector YY is given by Y=G(X)Y=G(X) and thus X=G−1(Y)=H(Y)X=G−1(Y)=H(Y). That is,
X=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢X1X2...Xn⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢H1(Y1,Y2,...,Yn)H2(Y1,Y2,...,Yn)...Hn(Y1,Y2,...,Yn)⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥.X=[X1X2...Xn]=[H1(Y1,Y2,...,Yn)H2(Y1,Y2,...,Yn)...Hn(Y1,Y2,...,Yn)].
Then, the PDF of Y, fY1,Y2,...,Yn(y1,y2,...,yn)fY1,Y2,...,Yn(y1,y2,...,yn), is given by
fY(y)=fX(H(y))|J|fY(y)=fX(H(y))|J|

where JJ is the Jacobian of HH defined by
J=det⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢∂H1∂y1∂H2∂y1⋮∂Hn∂y1∂H1∂y2∂H2∂y2⋮∂Hn∂y2......⋮...∂H1∂yn∂H2∂yn⋮∂Hn∂yn⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥,J=det[∂H1∂y1∂H1∂y2...∂H1∂yn∂H2∂y1∂H2∂y2...∂H2∂yn⋮⋮⋮⋮∂Hn∂y1∂Hn∂y2...∂Hn∂yn],
and evaluated at (y1,y2,...,yn)(y1,y2,...,yn).
Example
Let X be an nn-dimensional random vector. Let A be a fixed (non-random) invertible nn by nn matrix, and b be a fixed nn-dimensional vector. Define the random vector Y as
Y=AX+b.Y=AX+b.
Find the PDF of YY in terms of PDF of XX.
  • Solution
    • Since AA is invertible, we can write
      X=A−1(Y−b).X=A−1(Y−b).
      We can also check that
      J=det(A−1)=1det(A).J=det(A−1)=1det(A).
      Thus, we conclude that
      fY(y)=1|det(A)|fX(A−1(y−b)).fY(y)=1|det(A)|fX(A−1(y−b)).

Normal (Gaussian) Random Vectors:

We discussed two jointly normal random variables previously in Section 5.3.2. In particular, two random variables XX and YY are said to be bivariate normal or jointly normal, if aX+bYaX+bY has normal distribution for all a,b∈Ra,b∈R. We can extend this definition to nn jointly normal random variables.
Random variables X1X1, X2X2,..., XnXn are said to be jointly normal if, for all a1a1,a2a2,..., anan ∈R∈R, the random variable
a1X1+a2X2+...+anXna1X1+a2X2+...+anXn
is a normal random variable.

As before, we agree that the constant zero is a normal random variable with zero mean and variance, i.e., N(0,0)N(0,0). When we have several jointly normal random variables, we often put them in a vector. The resulting random vector is a called a normal (Gaussian) random vector.
A random vector
X=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢X1X2...Xn⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥X=[X1X2...Xn]
is said to be normal or Gaussian if the random variables X1X1, X2X2,..., XnXn are jointly normal.

To find the general form for the PDF of a Gaussian random vector it is convenient to start from the simplest case where the XiXi's are independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.), Xi∼N(0,1)Xi∼N(0,1). In this case, we know how to find the joint PDF. It is simply the product of the individual (marginal) PDFs. Let's call such a random vector the standard normal random vector. So, let
Z=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢Z1Z2...Zn⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥,Z=[Z1Z2...Zn],
where ZiZi's are i.i.d. and Zi∼N(0,1)Zi∼N(0,1). Then, we have
fZ(z)=fZ1,Z2,...,Zn(z1,z2,...,zn)=∏i=1nfZi(zi)=1(2π)n2exp{−12∑i=1nz2i}=1(2π)n2exp{−12zTz}.fZ(z)=fZ1,Z2,...,Zn(z1,z2,...,zn)=∏i=1nfZi(zi)=1(2π)n2exp⁡{−12∑i=1nzi2}=1(2π)n2exp⁡{−12zTz}.
For a standard normal random vector Z, where ZiZi's are i.i.d. and Zi∼N(0,1)Zi∼N(0,1), the PDF is given by
fZ(z)=1(2π)n2exp{−12zTz}.fZ(z)=1(2π)n2exp⁡{−12zTz}.

Now, we need to extend this formula to a general normal random vector X with mean mm and covariance matrix C. This is very similar to when we defined general normal random variables from the standard normal random variable. We remember that if Z∼N(0,1)Z∼N(0,1), then the random variable X=σZ+μX=σZ+μ has N(μ,σ2)N(μ,σ2) distribution. We would like to do the same thing for normal random vectors.

Assume that I have a normal random vector X with mean mm and covariance matrix C. We write X∼N(m,C)X∼N(m,C). Further, assume that CC is a positive definite matrix.(The positive definiteness assumption here does not create any limitations. We already know that CC is positive semi-definite (Theorem 6.2), so det(C)≥0det(C)≥0. We also know that CC is positive definite if and only if det(C)>0det(C)>0 (Theorem 6.3). So here, we are only excluding the case det(C)=0det(C)=0. If det(C)=0det(C)=0, then you can show that you can write some XiXi's as a linear combination of others, so indeed we can remove them from the vector without losing any information.) Then from linear algebra we know that there exists an nn by nn matrix Q such that

QQT=I(I is the identity matrix),C=QDQT,QQT=I(I is the identity matrix),C=QDQT,
where D is a diagonal matrix
D=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢d110...00d22...0............00...dnn⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥.D=[d110...00d22...0............00...dnn].
The positive definiteness assumption guarantees that all diidii's are positive. Let's define
D12=⎡⎣⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢⎢d11−−−√0...00d22−−−√...0............00...dnn−−−√⎤⎦⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥⎥.D12=[d110...00d22...0............00...dnn].
We have D12D12=DD12D12=D and D12=D12TD12=D12T. Also define
A=QD12QT.A=QD12QT.
Then,
AAT=ATA=C.AAT=ATA=C.
Now we are ready to define the transformation that converts a standard Gaussian vector to X∼N(m,C)X∼N(m,C). Let Z be a standard Gaussian vector, i.e., Z∼N(0,I)Z∼N(0,I). Define
X=AZ+m.X=AZ+m.
We claim that X∼N(m,C)X∼N(m,C). To see this, first note that XX is a normal random vector. The reason is that any linear combination of components of XX is indeed a linear combination of components of ZZ plus a constant. Thus, every linear combination of components of XX is a normal random variable. It remains to show that EX=mEX=m and CX=CCX=C. First note that by linearity of expectation we have
EX=E[AZ+m]=AE[Z]+m=m.EX=E[AZ+m]=AE[Z]+m=m.
Also, by Example 6.12 we have
CX=ACZAT=AAT=C.(since CZ=I)CX=ACZAT=AAT(since CZ=I)=C.
Thus, we have shown that X is a random vector with mean mm and covariance matrix C. Now we can use Example 6.15 to find the PDF of X. We have
fX(x)=1|det(A)|fZ(A−1(x−m))=1(2π)n2|det(A)|exp{−12(A−1(x−m))T(A−1(x−m))}=1(2π)n2det(C)−−−−−−√exp{−12(x−m)TA−TA−1(x−m)}=1(2π)n2det(C)−−−−−−√exp{−12(x−m)TC−1(x−m)}.fX(x)=1|det(A)|fZ(A−1(x−m))=1(2π)n2|det(A)|exp⁡{−12(A−1(x−m))T(A−1(x−m))}=1(2π)n2det(C)exp⁡{−12(x−m)TA−TA−1(x−m)}=1(2π)n2det(C)exp⁡{−12(x−m)TC−1(x−m)}.

For a normal random vector XX with mean mm and covariance matrix CC, the PDF is given by
fX(x)=1(2π)n2detC−−−−−√exp{−12(x−m)TC−1(x−m)}(6.1)fX(x)=1(2π)n2detCexp⁡{−12(x−m)TC−1(x−m)}(6.1)

Example
Let XX and YY be two jointly normal random variables with X∼N(μX,σX)X∼N(μX,σX), Y∼N(μY,σY)Y∼N(μY,σY), and ρ(X,Y)=ρρ(X,Y)=ρ. Show that the above PDF formula for PDF of [XY][XY] is the same as fX,Y(x,y)fX,Y(x,y) given in Definition 5.4 in Section 5.3.2. That is,
fXY(x,y)=12πσXσY1−ρ2−−−−−√⋅exp{−12(1−ρ2)[(x−μXσX)2+(y−μYσY)2−2ρ(x−μX)(y−μY)σXσY]}.fXY(x,y)=12πσXσY1−ρ2⋅exp⁡{−12(1−ρ2)[(x−μXσX)2+(y−μYσY)2−2ρ(x−μX)(y−μY)σXσY]}.
  • Solution
    • Both formulas are in the form ae−12bae−12b. Thus, it suffices to show that they have the same aa and bb. Here we have
      m=[μXμY].m=[μXμY].
      We also have
      C=[Var(X)Cov(Y,X)Cov(X,Y)Var(Y)]=[σ2XρσXσYρσXσYσ2Y].C=[Var(X)Cov(X,Y)Cov(Y,X)Var(Y)]=[σX2ρσXσYρσXσYσY2].
      From this, we obtain
      detC=σ2Xσ2Y(1−ρ2).detC=σX2σY2(1−ρ2).
      Thus, in both formulas for PDF aa is given by
      a=12πσXσY1−ρ2−−−−−√.a=12πσXσY1−ρ2.
      Next, we check bb. We have
      C−1=1σ2Xσ2Y(1−ρ2)[σ2Y−ρσXσY−ρσXσYσ2X].C−1=1σX2σY2(1−ρ2)[σY2−ρσXσY−ρσXσYσX2].
      Now by matrix multiplication we obtain
      (x−m)TC−1(x−m)==1σ2Xσ2Y(1−ρ2)[x−μXy−μY]T[σ2Y−ρσXσY−ρσXσYσ2X][x−μXy−μY]=−12(1−ρ2)[(x−μXσX)2+(y−μYσY)2−2ρ(x−μX)(y−μY)σXσY],(x−m)TC−1(x−m)==1σX2σY2(1−ρ2)[x−μXy−μY]T[σY2−ρσXσY−ρσXσYσX2][x−μXy−μY]=−12(1−ρ2)[(x−μXσX)2+(y−μYσY)2−2ρ(x−μX)(y−μY)σXσY],
      which agrees with the formula in Definition 5.4.

Remember that two jointly normal random variables XX and YY are independent if and only if they are uncorrelated. We can extend this to multiple jointly normal random variables. Thus, if you have a normal random vector whose components are uncorrelated, you can conclude that the components are independent. To show this, note that if the XiXi's are uncorrelated, then the covariance matrix CXCX is diagonal, so its inverse C−1XCX−1 is also diagonal. You can see that in this case the PDF (Equation 6.1) becomes the products of marginal PDFs.
If X=[X1,X2,...,Xn]TX=[X1,X2,...,Xn]T is a normal random vector, and we know Cov(Xi,Xj)=0Cov(Xi,Xj)=0 for all i≠ji≠j, then X1X1,X2X2, ..., XnXn are independent.

Another important result is that if X=[X1,X2,...,Xn]TX=[X1,X2,...,Xn]T is a normal random vector then Y=AX+bY=AX+b is also a random vector because any linear combination of components of YY is also a linear combination of components of XX plus a constant value.
If X=[X1,X2,...,Xn]TX=[X1,X2,...,Xn]T is a normal random vector, X∼N(m,C)X∼N(m,C), AA is an mm by nn fixed matrix, and bb is an mm-dimensional fixed vector, then the random vector Y=AX+bY=AX+b is a normal random vector with mean AEX+bAEX+b and covariance matrix ACATACAT.
Y∼N(AEX+b,ACAT)Y∼N(AEX+b,ACAT)
